title: Misleading "slices are iterators" hint

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

labels.name: D-verbose
labels.description: Too much output caused by a single piece of incorrect code

body:
[Given this code](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=bf624fa2e446f0a81a094ad8e4cca971)

```rust
fn main() {
    let a = [1,2,3];
    for i in a {}
}
```

One of the notes in error message says

```
note: arrays are not iterators, but slices like the following are: `&[1, 2, 3]`
```

However slices are also not iterators, but can be converted to an iterator as indicated by another note in the same message as the requirement that isn't met

```
note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `IntoIterator` for `[{integer}; 3]`
```
The full error message is:
```
error[E0277]: `[{integer}; 3]` is not an iterator
 --> r.rs:3:14
  |
3 |     for i in a {}
  |              ^ borrow the array with `&` or call `.iter()` on it to iterate over it
  |
  = help: the trait `Iterator` is not implemented for `[{integer}; 3]`
  = note: arrays are not iterators, but slices like the following are: `&[1, 2, 3]`
  = note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `IntoIterator` for `[{integer}; 3]`
  = note: required by `into_iter`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
```

This came up while helping someone learn the language and was rather confusing.

### Meta

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.50.0 (cb75ad5db 2021-02-10)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: cb75ad5db02783e8b0222fee363c5f63f7e2cf5b
commit-date: 2021-02-10
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.50.0
```
